Authors: Li W., Ching T.W.
Title: Ultrahigh-speed flywheel energy storage for electric vehicles
Source title: Energy Systems for Electric and Hybrid Vehicles
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Department of Electromechanical Engineering, University of Macau, Macao, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, W., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Ching, T.W., Department of Electromechanical Engineering, University of Macau, Macao, China
Abstract: Flywheel energy storage systems (FESSs) have been investigated in many industrial applications, ranging from conventional industries to renewables, for stationary emergency energy supply and for the delivery of high energy rates in a short time period. FESSs can be used for industrial applications ranging from aerospace stations and railway trains to electric vehicles (EVs). They have their own individual advantages and disadvantages, leading them to have their own unique roles for energy storage applications. Compared to the limitation of an electrochemical battery imposed by its inherent features, such as low power density, short duration of service, limited charge-discharge cycles and being environmentally unfriendly, FESSs exhibit some distinctive merits, such as high energy density, low cost, high reliability, high dynamics, long lifetime, high efficiency, environmental friendliness and easy monitoring of the state of charge. In this chapter, FESSs applied in EVs are discussed, with an emphasis on those operating at speeds over 10, 000 rpm. The organization of this chapter is as follows. In section 3.1, a brief introduction of FESSs is presented. In section 3.2, the configuration of an FESS, including a flywheel, a motor/generator, a bearing, a power converter and an enclosure, is described. Then, in section 3.3, possible candidates for ultrahigh-speed motors/generators for FESSs are reviewed. Lastly, in section 3.4, control strategies for motor/generator control, flywheel control and power flow control are discussed. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2016.

Authors: Chau K.T.
Title: Energy systems for electric and hybrid vehicles
Source title: Energy Systems for Electric and Hybrid Vehicles
Affiliations: The University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Chau, K.T., The University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong
Abstract: Electric and hybrid vehicles have been globally identified to be the most environmental friendly road transportation. Energy Systems for Electric and Hybrid Vehicles provides comprehensive coverage of the three main energy system technologies of these vehicles - energy sources, battery charging and vehicle-to-grid systems. The book begins with a discussion of energy source systems, covering electrochemical energy sources, flywheel energy storage, hybrid energy sources, solar energy harvesting, electromagnetic energy regeneration and thermoelectric energy recovery. Then battery technologies are covered, including battery charging strategies and battery management techniques, emerging wireless charging techniques for electric vehicles and the concept of energy cryptography for secure wireless power transfer. Finally vehicle-to-X technology is discussed, embracing the vehicle-to-home, vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-grid energy systems, for electric and hybrid vehicles. Combining insights from an international team of authors, this book is essential reading for researchers and advanced students developing electric/hybrid vehicles and intelligent transport systems in industry and academia. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2016.
Author Keywords: Battery management systems; Cryptography; Electric vehicles; Electromagnetic waves; Energy harvesting; Flywheels; Power grids; Radiofrequency power transmission; Secondary cells; Solar energy conversion; Thermoelectric conversion

Authors: Temizel C., Betancourt D.J., Tiwari A., Zhang M., Aktas S.S., Quiros F.
Title: Optimization of enhanced coalbed methane recovery with C02 injection
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE Argentina Exploration and Production of Unconventional Resources Symposium
Affiliations: Aera Energy, United States; Halliburton, United States; Pioneer Exploration, United States; University of Akron, United States; Turkish Petroleum, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Temizel, C., Aera Energy, United States; Betancourt, D.J., Halliburton, United States; Tiwari, A., Pioneer Exploration, United States; Zhang, M., University of Akron, United States; Aktas, S.S., Turkish Petroleum, Turkey; Quiros, F., Halliburton, United States
Abstract: Objectives/Scope: Coalbed methane (CBM) has become an important source of clean energy in the recent decades worldwide including the US, China, Australia, India and Russia with more than 60 countries having different degrees of promising coal reserves. CBM reservoirs are distinguished from conventional reservoirs due to the major difference in the mechanism of gas storage and production of water. In CBM reservoirs, pores act as the major storage mechanism as gas is trapped and stored there and produced by means of dewatering and thus lowering the reservoir pressure. Free gas forms as the pressure is lowered leading to increased gas permeability of coal and thus increasing recovery. Microbial activity and thermal maturation of organic compounds are the main mechanisms of methane generation in lower-and-higher rank coals, respectively. Even though methane is an abundant and clean energy source, there are certain operational, technical and economic challenges involved in its production due its unique nature outlined above. Thus, a strong understanding of the parameters and uncertainties that influence the recovery is crucial. Methods, Procedures, Process: Due to the fact that the organic materials that make up coals generally have a stronger affinity for CO2 than for methane, CO2 is used as an enhanced recovery method to displace methane as an enhanced coalbed methane recovery (ECBM) method. While there is no current comprehensive optimization study on the effects of such factors, ECBM has a very significant role in the future of energy as it means more energy out of natural gas while eliminating the adverse effects of greenhouse gases. Results, Observations, Conclusions: In this study, a standard SPE reservoir simulation model is used to study the factors influencing the recovery in coal bed methane reservoirs by investigating the significance of parameters including but not limited to porosity, adsorption capacity, fracture permeability along with coal density and irreducible water saturation. Novel/Additive Information: The optimization results obtained by means of coupling a full-physics commercial numerical reservoir simulator with an optimization/uncertainty tool are presented outlining the different degrees of significance of these factors on production and ultimate recovery for better understanding of the phenomenon that will lead to more robust reservoir management decisions. Copyright 2016, Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Coal; Coal bed methane; Coal deposits; Enhanced recovery; Firedamp; Gas permeability; Greenhouse gases; Metal recovery; Methane; Petroleum reservoir engineering; Proven reserves; Resource valuation; Adsorption capacities; Clean energy sources; Comprehensive optimizations; Enhanced coalbed methane recoveries; Fracture permeability; Irreducible water saturation; Microbial activities; Reservoir simulation model; Reservoir management

Authors: Akintola A., Barlow J., Cooke E., Fynn W., Hansen H., Heim M., Jackson R., Mennes S., Pendrey D., Perkins B., Popat N., Thomas J.
Title: Construction site safety standardisation
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE International Conference and Exhibition on Health, Safety, Security, Environment, and Social Responsibility
Affiliations: Shell Global Solutions International, United States; Shell Chemicals Americas Inc., United States; Shell Global Solutions SDN.Bhd, Malaysia; Shell Global Solutions US Inc., United States; Shell International Exploration and Production, United States
Authors with affiliations: Akintola, A., Shell Global Solutions International, United States; Barlow, J., Shell Global Solutions International, United States; Cooke, E., Shell Global Solutions International, United States; Fynn, W., Shell Chemicals Americas Inc., United States; Hansen, H., Shell Global Solutions SDN.Bhd, Malaysia; Heim, M., Shell Global Solutions US Inc., United States; Jackson, R., Shell International Exploration and Production, United States; Mennes, S.; Pendrey, D., Shell International Exploration and Production, United States; Perkins, B., Shell International Exploration and Production, United States; Popat, N., Shell International Exploration and Production, United States; Thomas, J., Shell International Exploration and Production, United States
Abstract: As part of the Royal Dutch Shell Group, the Shell Projects organisation, which is responsible for all major construction projects in Shell, shares the Shell-wide Goal Zero aspiration of no harm and no leaks. To help accelerate the journey to Goal Zero, a set of standard safety rules and a roadmap of activities that can help to deliver strong safety leadership have been implemented across all construction sites and installation vessels. This paper will describe the development of this initiative, which is known as Construction Site Safety Standardisation (CSSS), outline its key components and their purpose, and demonstrate how CSSS is impacting the global projects construction sites that are essential to the continued growth of Shell as an energy provider and petrochemical company. CSSS grew out of an analysis of how workers were getting hurt, mainly based on Shell's own data, but also using some wider industry information. A hot spot analysis was made of incident types, including near misses with serious injury potential. The following activities were identified as the most hazardous: 1. Confined Spaces 2. Excavations 3. Heavy Equipment and Vehicle Operations 4. Hot Works 5. Lifting and Hoisting 6. Safe Isolation of Energy 7. Scaffolding and other forms of access 8. Simultaneous Operations 9. Working at Height Requirements that were specific to construction/installation activities were then developed to reinforce and complement already existing cross-Shell HSSE requirements. Standards were also developed for the following safe practices that were regarded as further construction-wide contributory factors in safety performance: y Barricades and Open Holes y Housekeeping y Line of Fire y Personal Protective Equipment y Routine Life Tasks The new, extended requirements, supported by visual materials and toolbox talks, are designed to promote safer work among both employees and contractor staff as well as cross-pollinate lessons learned and best practices across the global projects portfolio. The requirement to use a 'roadmap' of enabling activities, supported by a structured set of consistent materials and job aids, reduces waste and streamlines approaches to building worksite safety cultures. This, in turn, improves experience transfer and learning and avoids the potential of continual reinvention of initiatives across projects. Roadmap activities are clustered into five areas: Safety Leadership; Care for People; Staffing, Training, Competency; Communications; and Worksite Set-up. CSSS was initially back-integrated into existing projects and is now an integral part of the start-up of new projects. Consistent uptake across projects is helping to establish a single, global approach to construction site safety management. This paper will include some project examples to show how CSSS is helping to drive positive change and promote consistency in different environments-including greenfield and brownfield sites and vessels-and across projects with varying governance models. Copyright 2016, Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Construction equipment; Digital storage; Financial markets; Personnel training; Protective clothing; Shells (structures); Social aspects; Standardization; Construction site safety; Contributory factors; Installation vessels; Major construction project; Personal protective equipment; Petrochemical company; Safety performance; Simultaneous operation; Project management

Authors: Olsson D., Andersson J., Curbis F., Isaksson L., Malmgren L., Mansten E., Thorin S.
Title: Commissioning status of the chopper system for the Max IV injector
Source title: Proceedings of the 28th Linear Accelerator Conference, LINAC 2016
Affiliations: MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Olsson, D., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden; Andersson, J., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden; Curbis, F., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden; Isaksson, L., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden; Malmgren, L., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden; Mansten, E., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden; Thorin, S., MAX IV Laboratory, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: The MAX IV facility in Lund, Sweden consists of two storage rings for production of synchrotron radiation, and a short-pulse-facility (SPF). The two rings are designed for 3 GeV and 1.5 GeV, respectively, where the initial beam commissioning of the former has recently been completed, and commissioning of the latter was started in September 2016. Both rings will be operating with top-up injections delivered by a full-energy injector. In order to reduce losses of high-energy electrons along the injector and in the rings during injection, only electrons that are within a time structure where they can be accumulated in the ring buckets are accelerated. Electrons outside this time structure are dumped before they reach the first LINAC structure by a chopper system. The performance of the chopper system during commissioning of the 3 GeV ring is presented in this paper. Copyright © 2017 CC-BY-3.0 and by the respective authors.
Index Keywords: Choppers (circuits); Linear accelerators; Synchrotron radiation; Chopper systems; High-energy electron; Short pulse; Germanium compounds

Authors: Gao S., Zhang Z., Liu C.
Title: Vehicle-to-home, vehicle-to-vehicle, and vehicle-to-grid energy systems
Source title: Energy Systems for Electric and Hybrid Vehicles
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Tianjin University, China; School of Energy and Environment, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Gao, S., School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Tianjin University, China; Zhang, Z., School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Tianjin University, China; Liu, C., School of Energy and Environment, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: As a large market share of electric vehicles (EVs) is expected in the transportation section, the high penetration of EVs in the power grid has placed new challenges on the power system planning and operation. Their negative impacts on energy supply, transformer deterioration, and peak demand increment are revealed. Therefore, control methods for integrating EVs into the power grid are developed to mitigate the negative effects and exploit the aggregated EVs as energy storage devices to provide ancillary services. In this chapter, the vehicle-to-grid (V2G) operation in modern power system and its control framework are first introduced, which combines communication and EV charging infrastructures. Then, three different operation modes of EVs integrated to the power grid are described, which consists of vehicle-to-home (V2H), vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V), and V2G. The modeling and the control methods for these three operation modes are given. The planning of EV charging infrastructure and the ancillary services provided by V2G are discussed. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2016.

Authors: Nguyen T.-V., Carranza-Sánchez Y.A., de Oliveira Júnior S.
Title: A preliminary analysis of floating production storage and offloading facilities with gas liquefaction processes
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Laboratory of Environmental and Thermal Engineering, Polytechnic School – University of São Paulo, Av. Prof. Luciano Gualberto, São Paulo, 05508-900, Brazil; Section of Thermal Energy, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, Nils Koppels Allé, Kongens Lyngby, 2800, Denmark; School of Mechanical Technology – Technological University of Pereira, La Julita, Pereira, 660003, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, T.-V., Laboratory of Environmental and Thermal Engineering, Polytechnic School – University of São Paulo, Av. Prof. Luciano Gualberto, São Paulo, 05508-900, Brazil, Section of Thermal Energy, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, Nils Koppels Allé, Kongens Lyngby, 2800, Denmark; Carranza-Sánchez, Y.A., Laboratory of Environmental and Thermal Engineering, Polytechnic School – University of São Paulo, Av. Prof. Luciano Gualberto, São Paulo, 05508-900, Brazil, School of Mechanical Technology – Technological University of Pereira, La Julita, Pereira, 660003, Colombia; de Oliveira Júnior, S., Laboratory of Environmental and Thermal Engineering, Polytechnic School – University of São Paulo, Av. Prof. Luciano Gualberto, São Paulo, 05508-900, Brazil
Abstract: Floating, production, storage and offloading (FPSO) plants are facilities used in upstream petroleum processing. They have gained interest because they are more flexible than conventional plants and can be used for producing oil and gas in deep-water fields. In general, gas export is challenging because of the lack of infrastructure in remote locations. The present work investigates the possibility of integrating liquefaction processes on such facilities, considering two mixed-refrigerant and two expansion-based processes suitable for offshore applications. Two FPSO configurations are considered in this work, and they were suggested by Brazilian operators for fields processing natural gas with moderate to high content of carbon dioxide. The performance of the combined systems is analysed by conducting energy and exergy analyses. The integration of gas liquefaction results in greater power consumption and exergy destruction than in the baseline cases with compression and injection. Gas liquefaction systems with expansion-based processes are the least performant: the exergy destruction reaches up to 50 MW, and may represent up to 120% of the exergy destruction in the processing plant. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: Gas liquefaction; Oil platforms; Process integration; Thermodynamic analysis

Authors: Olsen D., Abdelouadoud Y., Wellig B., Krummenacher P.
Title: Systematic thermal energy storage integration in industry using pinch analysis
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Horw, Switzerland; Haute École d'Ingénierie et de Gestion du Canton de Vaud, Yverdon-les-Bains, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Olsen, D., Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Horw, Switzerland; Abdelouadoud, Y., Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Horw, Switzerland; Wellig, B., Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Horw, Switzerland; Krummenacher, P., Haute École d'Ingénierie et de Gestion du Canton de Vaud, Yverdon-les-Bains, Switzerland
Abstract: Industrial energy use is responsible for a large portion of the total energy consumption in industrialized countries around the world. In Switzerland, for example, the consumption represents approximately 20% of which more than half is used for process heat. To determine how to optimize the use of industrial thermal energy, process integration and pinch analysis methods are used. However, a particular challenge exists in energy optimization of batch and semi-continuous processes commonly found in industry. For such processes direct heat recovery is limited and dependent on the schedule limiting its broad industrial application. Development in recent years in this field has focused on indirect heat recovery using thermal energy storage integration to provide a practical solution to the heat integration of non-continuous processes. A methodology for the conceptual design of a thermal energy storage system and an overview of the calculations based on the indirect sources & sinks profiles are presented. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: Batch Process; Heat Exchanger Network; Indirect Heat Recovery; Pinch Analysis; Thermal Energy Storage

Authors: Fanti G.R., Donato G.H.B., de Mello P.E.B.
Title: A novel scroll expander for flank leakage investigation: Preliminary tests
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Centro Universitário da FEI, av. Humberto de Alencar Castelo Branco, 3972, São Bernardo do Campo, SP, CEP 09850-901, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Fanti, G.R., Centro Universitário da FEI, av. Humberto de Alencar Castelo Branco, 3972, São Bernardo do Campo, SP, CEP 09850-901, Brazil; Donato, G.H.B., Centro Universitário da FEI, av. Humberto de Alencar Castelo Branco, 3972, São Bernardo do Campo, SP, CEP 09850-901, Brazil; de Mello, P.E.B., Centro Universitário da FEI, av. Humberto de Alencar Castelo Branco, 3972, São Bernardo do Campo, SP, CEP 09850-901, Brazil
Abstract: The isentropic efficiency of the expander is a concern for organic Rankine cycle (ORC) and compressed air energy storage (CAES) implementation. In these applications, the expander alone has a great influence over the whole system efficiency. Scroll expanders are particularly interesting for the low power range comprehended between 1 and 10 kW. Many previous works have attributed to internal leakages a great importance to obtain high isentropic efficiency in these machines. We present herein experimental results obtained with a novel scroll expander constructed to investigate the effect of internal leakages. We discuss the geometry definition and design of the prototype in detail. The maximum mechanical power produced by the prototype was 923 W at 2690 rpm but its isentropic efficiency was only 30.6%. Filling factor as high as 4.9 reveals that internal leakage must be reduced to obtain a more efficient expander. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: CAES; Clearance; Isentropic efficiency; Leakage; Novel scroll expander; ORC

Authors: Wang L., Gregory D., Suciu R.-A., Marechal F.
Title: Time-dependent performance of an integrated solar-driven hydrogen generation device
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Industrial Process and Energy Systems Engineering, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Rue de L’industrie 17, Case Postale 440, Sion, 1951, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wang, L., Industrial Process and Energy Systems Engineering, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Rue de L’industrie 17, Case Postale 440, Sion, 1951, Switzerland; Gregory, D., Industrial Process and Energy Systems Engineering, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Rue de L’industrie 17, Case Postale 440, Sion, 1951, Switzerland; Suciu, R.-A., Industrial Process and Energy Systems Engineering, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Rue de L’industrie 17, Case Postale 440, Sion, 1951, Switzerland; Marechal, F., Industrial Process and Energy Systems Engineering, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Rue de L’industrie 17, Case Postale 440, Sion, 1951, Switzerland
Abstract: A promising alternative for solar-energy storage is to directly capture, convert and store photon flux in form of flexible and transferable solar fuels, especially hydrogen. The cost-effective design and operation of solar-integrated hydrogen generation devices is complicated and challenging, e. g., the performance mismatch of solar cell and electrolyzer is not favorable for improving the solar-to-hydrogen efficiency. In this paper, a solar-driven hydrogen generator (shine.epfl.ch), which highly integrates self-tracking concentrator, high-efficient waveguide, serial-connected light absorber and vapor-feed electrolyzer is modelled in a steady-state 0-dimensional fashion. The model considers the variations of the component performances regarding to different operating temperatures and is calibrated with experimental results. The optimal design of the device is then carried out considering proper heat integration at the system level. Time-dependent optimal mass-energy balance of the whole device, therefore, are established, which could serve for the optimal synthesis of distributed energy supply systems when considering this hydrogen generation device. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: Integrated eletrolyzer; Solar-to-hydrogen; Time-dependent performance

Authors: Suciu R., Stadler P., Ashouri A., Maréchal F.
Title: Towards energy-autonomous cities using CO2 networks and Power to Gas storage
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Suciu, R., Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland; Stadler, P., Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland; Ashouri, A., Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland; Maréchal, F., Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Under Energy Strategy 2050, the federal government of Switzerland plans to greatly reduce per capita energy consumption, decrease the share of fossil fuels, and replace the nuclear electricity generation by gains in efficiency and use of renewable energy sources. This work investigates the feasibility of defined goals through both the improvement of the efficiency of current energy systems and the increase in renewable energy sources. For efficiency improvement, a new district energy network is proposed. District heating and cooling networks - usually use centralized, energy efficient conversion technologies based on water networks, which is not suitable for multi-temperature supply and heat recovery. This work investigates a network using CO2 as a refrigerant for heat transfer. The system utilizes the latent heat of vaporization as the main source of storage and transfer of heat, and allows for recovery of waste heat from cooling in heating, due to the two-pipe system. This study also investigates the potential of this CO2 network when coupled with renewable energy sources to satisfy the heating, cooling, and electricity requirements of urban areas in Switzerland. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: CO2 networks; District heating and cooling; Renewable energy sources; Self-sufficiency; Urban energy systems

Authors: Quoilin S., Zucker A.
Title: Techno-economic evaluation of self-consumption with PV/battery systems under different regulation schemes
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: European Commission, DG Joint Research Center, Institute for Energy and Transport, P.O. Box 2, ZG Petten, NL-1755, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Quoilin, S., European Commission, DG Joint Research Center, Institute for Energy and Transport, P.O. Box 2, ZG Petten, NL-1755, Netherlands; Zucker, A., European Commission, DG Joint Research Center, Institute for Energy and Transport, P.O. Box 2, ZG Petten, NL-1755, Netherlands
Abstract: The recent disclosure of new and innovative home battery systems has been seen by many as a catalyser for a solar energy revolution, and has created high expectations in the sector. Many observers have predicted an uptake of combined PV/Battery units, which, could ultimately disconnect from the grid and lead to autonomous homes or mini-grids. However, most of the comments originating from social media, blogs or press articles lack proper cost evaluation and realistic simulations. This work aims at bridging this gap by simulating self-consumption in different EU countries, for different household profiles with or without battery. Results indicate that (1) Although decreasing at a fast pace, the cost of domestic Li-Ion storage is most likely still too high for a large-scale market uptake in Europe; (2) PV incentives based on net metering are not favourable to home batteries; (3) Home battery profitability and future uptake mainly depend on the indirect self-consumption subsidies provided by the structure of the retail prices; (4) These systems do not allow residential consumers to go off-grid. They only allow for a maximum self-sufficiency ratio close to 70% © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: Battery; Household; Prosumer; PV; Self-Consumption

Authors: Gallo W.L.R., Gallego A.G., Acevedo V.L., Dias R., Ortiz H.Y., Valente B.A.
Title: Exergy analysis of the compression systems and its prime movers for a FPSO unit
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: State University of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Federal University of ABC, Santo André, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Gallo, W.L.R., State University of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Gallego, A.G., Federal University of ABC, Santo André, Brazil; Acevedo, V.L., State University of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Dias, R., State University of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Ortiz, H.Y., State University of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Valente, B.A., State University of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: The Brazilian production of oil and gas from offshore platforms tends to increase, due to the exploration and production of reservoirs in the so-called pre-salt basin. The associated gas is a mixture of hydrocarbons, water and inert gases that requires robust gas treatment and compression systems. Once treated, the streams of hydrocarbon gas and CO2-rich stream need to be exported by pipelines and/or reinjected into reservoirs. The electric motors of the hydrocarbon gas compressors are the largest energy consumers and are attached to the main power generation system. In turn, the CO2 compressors are driven mechanically by independent gas turbines. This paper aims to assess the performance of the compression systems and its prime movers, considering the off design operation of turbines, compressors, pumps and heat exchangers. Three conditions of well fluid composition and mass flow were modelled illustrating the maturity of the oil field. The methodology adopted in this assessment was the second law of thermodynamics. Identifying the major causes of irreversibility in each process can offer opportunities for improved energy use, exergy efficiencies and possibilities for waste heat recovery. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: Exergy method; Floating production storage; Gas compression; Offloading (FPSO)

Authors: Krawczyk P., Szabłowski Ł., Karellas S., Kakaras E., Badyda K.
Title: Comparative energy and exergy analysis of compressed air and liquid air energy storage systems
Source title: ECOS 2016 - Proceedings of the 29th International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimisation, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Institute of Heat Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Warsaw, Poland; National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Krawczyk, P., Institute of Heat Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Warsaw, Poland; Szabłowski, Ł., Institute of Heat Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Warsaw, Poland; Karellas, S., National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Kakaras, E., National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Badyda, K., Institute of Heat Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: Due to the intensive development of renewable energy, producing electricity in an irregular and unpredictable way, storage looks set to play an increasingly important role in the energy system. There are only two systems currently used to store electricity on a large scale: pumped storage and compressed air energy storage (CAES), whose respective special geographical requirements mean it is hard to find the right place to implement them in practical terms. This paper takes a comparative look at ‘geography-free’ liquid air energy storage (LAES) vis-à-vis systems based on compressed air, including balance calculations for selected configurations. A comprehensive energy and exergy analysis was conducted together with a comparison of storage volumes for the systems under consideration. © 2016 University of Ljubljana.
Author Keywords: Compressed air energy storage; Energy analysis; Liquid air energy storage; Storage efficiency

Authors: Andersson Å., Breunlin J., Jensen B.N., Lindvall R., Mansten E., Olsson D., Sundberg J., Tavares P.F., Thorin S.
Title: Diagnostics at the MAX IV 3 GeV storage ring during commissioning
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th International Beam Instrumentation Conference, IBIC 2016
Affiliations: MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Å., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Breunlin, J., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Jensen, B.N., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Lindvall, R., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Mansten, E., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Olsson, D., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Sundberg, J., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Tavares, P.F., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden; Thorin, S., MAX-IV Laboratory, Lund University, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: The MAX IV 3 GeV storage ring based on a multibend achromat lattice allows for horizontal emittances from 330 pm rad down to 180 pm rad, depending on the number of insertion devices. The diagnostics used during commissioning will be described, with emphasis on the emittance diagnostics. This will involve two diagnostic beam lines to image the electron beam with infrared and ultraviolet synchrotron radiation from bending magnets, in order to determine also beam energy spread. The scheme for horizontal emittance measurements looks promising also for an order of magnitude lower emittance. Bunch lengthening with harmonic cavities is essential for the low emittance machine performance. We have used a radiation-based sampling technique to verify individual bunch distributions. Authors: Lima A.A.B., Abreu F.
Title: Sobradinho Reservoir: Governance and Stakeholders
Affiliations: National Water Agency, Brasilia, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Lima, A.A.B., National Water Agency, Brasilia, Brazil; Abreu, F., National Water Agency, Brasilia, Brazil
Abstract: The São Francisco drainage basin covers 7.6 % of the Brazilian territory and has tremendous economic, social, and cultural importance for the country. About 60 % of its watershed is in the semi-arid region, which is characterized by having critical periods of drought. To regulate the river flow and to generate power, a cascade of hydropower plants was constructed on the São Francisco River. Among them is the Sobradinho Reservoir, which has an interannual water storage capacity to meet multiple water uses and adds about 4 billion kW of energy per year to the Brazilian northeast. In recent years, the average unregulated flow in the Sobradinho Reservoir has been lower than the historical average. The lowest average annual unregulated flow in the Sobradinho Reservoir occurred in 2014, and the first months of 2015 did not point to better conditions. The current and unfavorable hydrologic situation of the São Francisco Basin represents real governance challenges for Brazil. The minimum outflow from the Sobradinho Reservoir has been reduced several times to ensure that the needs for the multiple uses are met. Today, the Sobradinho Reservoir operates with a minimum outflow of 900 m3/s. Because of these reductions, there was a cumulative gain of 44.7 % in the active storage of the reservoir. If the mitigation measures that allowed reducing the minimum outflow had not been implemented, this reservoir would have fully depleted of its active storage by November 2014. © 2016, Springer Science+Business Media Singapore.
Author Keywords: Mitigation measures; Outflow; Regulated flow; Sobradinho Reservoir; São Francisco River

Authors: Al-Azawiey S.S., Hassan S.B.
Title: Heat absorption properties of ground material for solar chimney power plants
Source title: International Journal of Energy Production and Management
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Bandar Seri Iskandar, 32610, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Al-Azawiey, S.S., Mechanical Engineering Department, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Bandar Seri Iskandar, 32610, Malaysia; Hassan, S.B., Mechanical Engineering Department, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Bandar Seri Iskandar, 32610, Malaysia
Abstract: One of the major challenges to the widespread application of the solar chimney power plant is its low-power conversion efficiency because of the three technological processes involved. The chimney efficiency is difficult to improve, and thus enhancing the collector or turbine performance can considerably improve the total plant efficiency. This work focused on enhancing the energy conversion efficiency of the collector and also extending the operation time using a heat storage medium. The solar to thermal conversion and thermal storage capabilities of six ground materials that are potentially available in Malaysia were studied experimentally and numerically. The experimental model was designed such that the six materials were exposed to the same operation boundary conditions. The numerical studies were conducted using ANSYS software, where the geometrical models were developed and simulated using FLUENT for the fluid flow and energy/thermal field studies. The selected ground materials were ceramic, black stones, sawdust, dark-green painted wood, sand, and pebbles. The simulation and experimental results are in good agreement in terms of air stream velocity and energy conversion efficiency. The results showed that the different materials have different heat storage capacities, and that ceramics extend the operation with improved efficiency until nighttime. The results also showed that ceramic and black stones have better performance than the other materials. However, black stones are recommended as the absorbing material for solar chimney power plants in Malaysia and regional countries because they are readily available. © 2016 WIT Press, www.witpress.com.
Author Keywords: Absorption materials energy conversion; Absorptivity; Convective heat transfer; Solar chimney; Solar energy

Authors: Braun A., Diale M.M., Maabong K.D., Toth R.
Title: Safe and decentralised hydrogen fuel production and storage for residential building and mobility applications
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Disaster and Risk Conference: Integrative Risk Management - Towards Resilient Cities, IDRC Davos 2016
Affiliations: Empa, Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology, Dübendorf, Switzerland; University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; University of Botswana, Gaborone, Botswana
Authors with affiliations: Braun, A., Empa, Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology, Dübendorf, Switzerland; Diale, M.M., Empa, Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology, Dübendorf, Switzerland, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Maabong, K.D., Empa, Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology, Dübendorf, Switzerland, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa, University of Botswana, Gaborone, Botswana; Toth, R., Empa, Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology, Dübendorf, Switzerland
Abstract: Large scale facilities pose a potential risk and threat because with one isolated attack large damage can be obtained, for example in a city, potentially with a large number of human casualties. We present a solar energy harvesting strategy which allows for the generation of fuel for housing and mobility in a decentralised form. A city or a part of a city cannot be shut down from energy supply by a terrorist attack on this energy generation and storage infrastructure, because it is virtually fully decentralised and independent (no electric grid). This system is based on photo-electrochemical cell technology and takes advantage of the solar energy arriving at small landscapes in local neighbourhoods in the range of few 100 sqm area per operation unit. The fuel is hydrogen, or hydrocarbons such as methane or methanol, when carbon dioxide greenhouse gas is included in the chemical process cycle. The necessary water for the process may come from the local sewage waste-water system. The problem of energy storage after finish of sunshine during the day is also solved by this technology, because a storable fuel is produced. The pronounced safety feature of this approach is that many small units are built, which are impossible to demolish in a terror strike, as opposed to single large industrial complexes which are very attractive for terrorists to attack because of the high destructive "efficiency" by a single plot, but also by the commensurate public attention and "terror", literally, which comes with the attack on a landmark scale facility. The negative part in this calculation comes from the loss of efficiency by moving from few large units to many small units. This is likely the price which society has to pay for the gain in safety from terrorism. © 2016 CURRAN-CONFERENCE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Decentralized; Disaster; Explosion; Fuel supply; Solar hydrogen
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Carbon dioxide; Disasters; Energy harvesting; Explosions; Fuels; Greenhouse gases; Housing; Hydrogen storage; Plant shutdowns; Risk management; Sewage; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Decentralized; Fuel supply; Industrial complex; Loss of efficiencies; Residential building; Solar hydrogen; Storage infrastructure; Waste water systems; Terrorism

Authors: Lordan R., Spada M., Burgherr P.
Title: Qualitative risk assessment of coal combustion residue impoundment closure
Source title: Proceedings of the 6th International Disaster and Risk Conference: Integrative Risk Management - Towards Resilient Cities, IDRC Davos 2016
Affiliations: University of Chicago, Harris School of Public Policy, Chicago, United States; Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Lordan, R., University of Chicago, Harris School of Public Policy, Chicago, United States, Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland; Spada, M., Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland; Burgherr, P., Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: What are the risks involved with permanent disposal of coal ash; that is, the "closure" of disposal impoundments? Coal is one of the leading sources of energy globally; commensurately, Coal Combustion Residue (CCR) is the largest industrial waste stream. Typically, CCR collects as it is produced at the coal plant and stored in heaps or large impoundments until final disposal or "closure" of the disposal facility. The storage of this waste, prior to closure, lasts decades and can threaten human health and the environment should, for example, contaminants seep out of impoundments, or worse, should an accident occur (e.g. coal ash dam breach at TVA Kingston Fossil Plant in Tennessee, USA). The management practices of CCR facilities are similar to those of other mine tailings facilities. And, due to a lack in CCR disposal facility data, we draw additional information from tailings facility experience. Like similarly designed tailings disposal units, the closure of CCR impoundments retrofits the storage facility into a final disposal site. In both the CCR and tailings case, the impoundments are expected to remain for 100s to 1000s of years. But, how does the transition from storage to closure mitigate risks associated with CCR storage facilities? Unfortunately, the hazards and uncertainties of neither active nor closed impoundments are entirely understood, and therefore, how well the closure process reduces long-term risks is unclear. Our research characterizes the risks - hazards and the related uncertainties - of CCR disposal using data from U.S. tailings and CCR incidents. In the context of current CCR waste policy debates, we consider the potential hazards to human health and the environment posed both prior to and after closure to understand how different policy options can sustainably manage and regulate waste from producing energy to further enduring resilience. © 2016 CURRAN-CONFERENCE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Coal; Disposal; Resilience; Waste
Index Keywords: Coal; Coal ash; Coal storage; Digital storage; Disasters; Health hazards; Plant shutdowns; Risk assessment; Risk management; Solid wastes; Tailings; Tailings disposal; Waste disposal; Waste incineration; Wastes; Coal combustion residues; Disposal facilities; Industrial waste streams; Management practices; Permanent disposal; Qualitative risk assessment; Resilience; Storage facilities; Coal combustion

Authors: Wojdalski J., Grochowicz J., Ekielski A., Radecka K., Stępniak S., Orłowski A., Florczak I., Drożdż B., Żelaziński T., Kosmala G.
Title: Production and properties of apple pomace pellets and their suitability for energy generation purposes [Wytwarzanie, właściwości i możliwości zagospodarowania na cele energetyczne odpadowych wytłoków z przetwórstwa jabłek]
Affiliations: Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Warsaw School of Tourism and Hospitality Management, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Wojdalski, J., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Grochowicz, J., Warsaw School of Tourism and Hospitality Management, Poland; Ekielski, A., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Radecka, K., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Stępniak, S., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Orłowski, A., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Florczak, I., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Drożdż, B., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Żelaziński, T., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland; Kosmala, G., Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Poland
Abstract: The food processing industry, including fruit and vegetable processing sectors, produce significant quantities of waste and environmental pollutants. Food processing is a complex and demanding process because raw materials are supplied on a seasonal basis, they spoil easily and may be a source of microbiological contamination during production. Apple pomace is a by-product of fruit and vegetable processing, and it constitutes biodegradable waste. Small quantities of pomace are not harmful to the environment, but large amounts of waste could pose a problem for processing plants. Pressed pomace can be used in in-dustrial processing and power generation. This is one of the easiest pomace management methods, in particular in regions where large amounts of waste cannot be quickly processed into animal feed or where transport is not an option due to considerable distance. This paper presents the methodology and the results of analyses investigating the properties of apple pomace and its management scenarios. A review of published sources discussing the achievements in pomace management precedes the experimental part of this study. Samples of ground and unground apple pomace were analyzed to determine: granulometric composition – the size distribution of apple pomace fractions, pressure agglomeration, compaction energy and expansion of samples immediately after pressing and after 24 hours, the heat of combustion of the analyzed apple pomace, which was compared with the heat of combustion of other fruit and vegetable processing waste. The compaction energy of samples was determined with the use of a BLUEHILL-2 application for controlling the INSTRON 8802 machine. Material was subjected to compressive strength tests, and the expansion of samples was determined after 24 hours of storage. The total compaction energy of unground pomace ranged from 66.60 to 150.00 J·g-1, and of ground pomace from 34.79 to 149.95 J·g-1 at a temperature of 20°C and relative air humidity of 31.7%. The density of the resulting apple pomace pellets was determined in the range of 1114.0-1166.3 and 1114.0-1168.1 g·dm-3. The heat of combustion of pressed pomace samples, measured in a calorimeter, was 19 MJ·kg-1. The results of the study indicate that if apple pomace has net calorific value of 17.3 MJ·kg-1 and the effectiveness of a steam boiler reaches 70%, the amount of energy generated by the combustion of apple pellets is 80 to 340 times higher than the amount of energy consumed during processing under the load of 50 kN and 10 kN, respectively. The management of apple pomace in the production plant can serve as an example of a "waste-free" technology. The use of processed apple pomace for energy generation purposes may contribute to improving energy efficiency in production processes in fruit and vegetable processing plants. © 2018, Middle Pomeranian Scientific Society of The Environment Protection. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Apple pomace; Biomass energy; Heat of combustion; Pellets; Pressure agglomeration

Authors: Żukowski M.
Title: Assessment of the environmental effects resulting from the use of solar collectors [Ocena efektu ekologicznego wynikającego z zastosowania kolektorów słonecznych]
Affiliations: Politechnika Białostocka, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Żukowski, M., Politechnika Białostocka, Poland
Abstract: Climate and energy package is a set of rules designed by member states of European Union to combat climate change. According to these directives the greenhouse gas emissions should be reduced by 20% and the share of energy produced from renewable sources should simultaneously be increased by the same percentage. The use of solar collectors can both improve energy security and reduce the environmental impact caused by the thermal energy industry. An ability to reduce the pollutants, which can be achieved using devices for converting solar radiation into the heat, was determined in this paper. The environmental effect, discussed in the present work, is caused by reducing the demand for domestic water heating. This effect results from the application of thermal solar collectors. The amount of pollutants that are released into the air, emitted from combustion of fuels, was estimated on the basis of the annual energy gain from the solar radiation and emission factors of the selected pollutants recommended by the European Environment Agency (EEA). Net gain of energy from solar panels was determined on the basis of experimental data. The object of the study was the solar domestic hot water (SDHW) system located on the roof of the Hotel for the staff of Bialystok University of Technology (Poland). Experimental studies were carried out under the project financed by the Regional Operational Program of Podlasie Province – stage 1.1 named “Study of the effectiveness of active and passive methods to improve the energy efficiency of infrastructure supported by renewable energy sources”. The construction of the research object was the target of the stage – 5.2 named “Im-proving the energy efficiency of Bialystok University of Technology infrastructure by use of renewable energy sources” (V. Development of environmental protection infrastructure”). The system consists of two parallel-connected installations. The first includes 21 tube collectors with a total gross area of more than 74 m2 . The second unit consists of 35 flat plate collectors with a total gross area of about 72 m2 . Eight storage tanks with the capacity of 1000 liters each were placed in the basement of the Hotel. The monitoring system was used to record the installation parameters during its operation. It consists of 17 heat meters, 4 electricity recorders, and 42 platinum resistance temperature sensors. The weather station that captures the basic parameters of outside air and insolation is located near the solar collectors. As a result of studies, it was found that the solar system produced 230.61 GJ heat energy throughout the year. The equation necessary to determine an equivalent amount of energy that is produced in a power plant was presented in this paper. Subsequently, the value of a possible reduction of selected pollutant emissions, which are released into the air, was calculated. Moreover, ΔPj coefficients were proposed for determination of the emissions reduction related to 1 m2 gross area of a solar panel. The main conclusions from the assessment of the impact of applying SDHW system to reduce the air pollution in the urban area were presented at the end of the paper. © 2018, Middle Pomeranian Scientific Society of The Environment Protection. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Air pollutants; Climate and energy package; Renewable energy sources; Solar collectors; Solar domestic hot water system

Authors: Hamdioui S., Taouil M., du Nguyen H.A., Haron A., Xie L., Bertels K.
Title: CIM100X: Computation in-memory architecture based on resistive devices
Source title: International Workshop on Cellular Nanoscale Networks and their Applications
Affiliations: Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Hamdioui, S., Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Taouil, M., Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; du Nguyen, H.A., Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Haron, A., Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Xie, L., Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Bertels, K., Computer Engineering, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands
Abstract: In this paper, we briefly discuss a new proposed architecture, Computation-In-Memory (CIM) architecture, that targets specifically data-intensive applications. The architecture consists of the interwoven placement of computing and storage units, which are physically tightly integrated together inside a non-volatile memristor crossbar. The architecture has the potential of improving the energy-delay product, computing efficiency and performance per area by at least two orders of magnitude with respect to conventional CMOS architectures. © VDE VERLAG GMBH.

Authors: De Oliveira Miguel A.M.R., Regitano-Neto A., Mourad A.L., Henriques E.A., Ives R.M.V.A., Moitinho D.
Title: Evaluation of the packaging effect on the stability of sunflower meal from biodiesel production (66)
Source title: IAPRI 2016 - 20th World Conference on Packaging: Innovation, Development and Sustainability in Packaging, Proceedings
Affiliations: Food Chemistry and Applied Nutrition Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CCQA, Brazil; Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation, Embrapa Semi-Arid, Embrapa, Brazil; Packaging Technology Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CETEA, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: De Oliveira Miguel, A.M.R., Food Chemistry and Applied Nutrition Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CCQA, Brazil; Regitano-Neto, A., Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation, Embrapa Semi-Arid, Embrapa, Brazil; Mourad, A.L., Packaging Technology Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CETEA, Brazil; Henriques, E.A., Food Chemistry and Applied Nutrition Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CCQA, Brazil; Ives, R.M.V.A., Packaging Technology Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CETEA, Brazil; Moitinho, D., Packaging Technology Center/ITAL, Institute of Food Technology, CETEA, Brazil
Abstract: The biodiesel industry in Brazil and worldwide has grown steadily due to the search for alternative renewable fuels to fossil. The NPBP - National Program for Biodiesel Production and Use, set up by Law 11097/2005, encourages the production of biofuels from various oil sources. Biodiesel production from sunflower seeds has proved to be a form of aggregate income mainly for small farmers. As the meal originating from pressing accounts for about 60% of the original seeds, its subsequent use is of great importance for the economic viability of the process. Due to the seasonality of any biomass, the aim of this study was to evaluate the stability of meals originating from three sunflower genotypes (OL5, He 250 and He 253) placed into two types of packaging: PET/PE - polyethylene terephthalate laminated with white pigmented polyethylene and raffia/PE - raffia laminated with stored low density polyethylene. The meal was stored at constant temperature and humidity condition (25°C/75%RH) for 300 days. During this period, moisture content and the peroxide value of the meal were monitored. The study revealed that the three types of meal did not suffer significant loss of quality in the conditions evaluated after 10 months of storage, although all of them had different characteristics. OL5 meal was the most stable, and its peroxide value remained around 1mEq/kg throughout the storage. The He 250 press meal reached the range of 6-8 mEq/kg and the He 253 as high as 8-9 mEq/kg. The results obtained during storage showed that different packaging materials affected both the moisture and peroxide values. The peroxide levels achieved in meal packed in PET/PE packaging, were on average half of the other, showing therefore that this material provides better preservation of press meal than the laminated raffia. © 2016 CETEA - Packaging Technology Center. All rights reserved.

Authors: Yesiloglu E., Yildirim D., Oztekin Y.B.
Title: Effect of loading position and storage duration on the mechanical properties of abate fetel pear variety
Source title: TAE 2016 - Proceedings of 6th International Conference on Trends in Agricultural Engineering 2016
Affiliations: Black Sea Agricultural Research Institute, Samsun, Turkey; Department of Agricultural Machinery, Faculty of Agriculture, Ondokuz Mayis University, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Yesiloglu, E., Department of Agricultural Machinery, Faculty of Agriculture, Ondokuz Mayis University, Turkey; Yildirim, D., Black Sea Agricultural Research Institute, Samsun, Turkey; Oztekin, Y.B., Department of Agricultural Machinery, Faculty of Agriculture, Ondokuz Mayis University, Turkey
Abstract: In the study, the mechanical properties of Abbate Fetel pear have been examined in terms of storage time and loadingposition. The experiments were conducted in two stages; the first experiment was carried out immediately after the harvest and the second experiment was carried out after 30 days in cold storage. The mechanic properties of the pear fruit such as rupture force, deformation, rupture energy and firmness have been examined on the fruit’s bloom side, lateral side and stem side. Furthermore, the size, sphericity, mass, amount of soluble solids and volume of the pear fruit have been determined. The relationship between the sides of the fruit and firmness has been found as statistically significant (P<0.001). The maximum firmness value has been found at the stem side, while the lowest firmness value has been found at the bloom side. The lowest rupture energy value of the pear fruit has been determined to be needed at the bloom side. © 2016 Czech University of Life Sciences Prague. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Majdi H.M.A., Li Z.
Title: Mechanical and thermal insulation properties of high volume fly ash fiber reinforced cement composite (HVFA-FRCC) manufactured by extrusion technique
Affiliations: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Majdi, H.M.A., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Li, Z., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: As sustainability issue moves to the forefront of construction and building industry, utilizing waste materials for partial replacement of Portland cement and consequently decreasing Co2 emission has received much more attention. This study presents thermal insulation and mechanical properties of high volume fly ash fiber reinforced cement composite (HVFA-FRCC) manufacture by extrusion. The objective of this study is to improve thermal insulation properties of high volume fly ash fiber reinforced cement composite with acceptable mechanical properties to be used for building façade. Paraffin (PA) as an organic phase change material(PCM) was directly incorporated into porous structure of expanded perlite (EP) as light weight aggregate and formed PCM composite .TGA (thermo gravimetric analysis) results revealed the PCM composite is stable in the outdoor environment temperature. Steady thermal test showed that incorporation of PCM composite in the extruded panels enhances temperature differences between inner and outer surfaces of panel indicating that PCM is effective for thermal energy storage purpose. Moreover, extrusion technique improves flexural toughness of panels in spite of reduction of flexural strength in PCM incorporated specimens due to dilution of matrix by phase change materials. Our studies showed that HVFA extruded fiber reinforced cement composites with phase change material has a great potential to be used as building façade due to its high energy storage property as well as using waste materials which makes it a sustainable construction material. © 2016 International Committee of the SCMT conferences. All rights reserved.

Authors: Carvalho A.T., Amorim H.P., Brasil F.S., Vilhena P.R.M., Carvalho D.S.
Title: Brazilian experience with development and deployment of an online pd monitoring system on rotating machines based on virtual instrumentation
Affiliations: Cepel, Brazil; Eletronorte, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Carvalho, A.T., Cepel, Brazil; Amorim, H.P., Cepel, Brazil; Brasil, F.S., Eletronorte, Brazil; Vilhena, P.R.M., Eletronorte, Brazil; Carvalho, D.S., Eletronorte, Brazil
Abstract: The measurement of partial discharges (PD), although still presenting technical challenges of interpretation and diagnosis, is still the only effective tool for online monitoring of the dielectric in high voltage rotating machinery. PD online monitoring (during normal operation of equipments) can be carried out continuously or by periodic measurements. In both cases, its initial cost involves permanent installation of PD sensors in the monitored machines, besides the measurement system itself. The permanent installation of coupling capacitors and measurement circuits in rotating machines is performed during a scheduled maintenance period, and such investment can be amortized in a short time, since the additional cost per subsequent measurement falls practically to zero. However, experience shows that PD monitoring in hydroelectric plants in Brazil is not yet a widely disseminated practice. In part, this is due to the fact that the PD assessment technique (in contrast to other predictive assessment techniques already well established, such as vibration monitoring) is significantly more complex and requires analysis from a qualified specialist. Moreover, the high cost of measurement instruments and continuous monitoring systems represents a significant barrier to the spread of PD monitoring. To make continuous monitoring of PD a more affordable reality for hydroelectric plants, Cepel Electrical Energy Research Center and Eletronorte (a subsidiary of the Brazilian power utility Eletrobras, responsible for the power generation, transmission and distribution in the states of the Amazon region) have applied a solution that originated from the development of a modular system for the measurement of PD based entirely on virtual instrumentation. In this article we present the design features of this system as well as the experience of Eletronorte with its use monitoring hydro generators. The earliest PD measurement systems were traditionally comprised of analogical signal processing circuits and an oscilloscope or a galvanometer where the results were presented in real time. The measurement results were stored in the form of handwriting notes or photographs taken from the visual indicators. Evolving from the analogical systems, the latest PD measurement instruments adopted digital technology. The analogical signal processing circuits were reduced to a minimum and replaced by digital processing in application specific integrated circuits (ASICs) or field programmable gate arrays (FPGAS). Such systems also benefited from the contribution of computational systems, enabling new forms of visualization, processing and storage of information. Furthermore, the bandwidth of the measurement systems has been expanded, enabling new types of signal processing such as source discrimination based on the detected waveform parameters of the PD pulses. More recently, with the improvement and dissemination of the acquisition and data processing technologies, virtual instrumentation systems are occupying a growing space both in the academy and in the various sectors of industry. Such systems are characterized by the use of general modular hardware and specific software developed by the user. As a result, virtual instrumentation systems have lower costs and greater flexibility, allowing greater adherence to the specific needs of each measurement. The proposed solution for PD measurement using virtual instrumentation involved defining architecture for the measurement system, the specification of suitable hardware modules and the development of signal processing algorithms and control software for the measurement of PD. The functional requirements originally proposed for a virtual instrumentation based PD measurement system were: Measurement in the HF band, i.e., from 1 to 30 MHz. Sequential measurement of all monitored channels, with a synchronized three-phase measurement option. Flexible number of channels, expandable by the addition of new modules. Standardization of measurement results and availability of data in the company's maintenance network. Centralized analysis of all monitored machines and measurement points, indicating those that require more detailed tracking. Connection and correlation with other systems, including operating parameters of the equipment and other monitoring systems. In this article we present the architecture of the developed system and the main results obtained so far. The system presents significant advances in monitoring technology and predictive diagnosis of rotating machines, with complete flexibility and significant cost savings. © 2016 CIGRE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Generator; Maintenance Engineering.; Online Monitoring; Partial Discharge; Predictive Diagnostic; Rotating Machine; Stator Winding; Virtual Instrumentation

Authors: Rowe M.W., Blinman E., Martin J.C., Cox J.R., Mackenzie M., Wacker L.
Title: A new cold plasma system for pictogram14C sampling [Nuevo sistema de plasma frío para la toma de muestras de14C en pictogramas]
Source title: Paleoart and Materiality: The Scientific Study of Rock Art
Affiliations: Center for New Mexico Archaeology, P.O. Box 2087, Santa Fe, NM  87504, United States; Conservation Unit, Museum of New Mexico, P.O. Box 2087, Santa Fe, NM  87504, United States; Laboratory of Ion Beam Physics, ETH Zűürich, HPK, H29, Otto-Stern-Weg 5, Züűrich, CH-8093, Switzerland

Box 2087, Santa Fe, NM  87504, United States; Martin, J.C., Center for New Mexico Archaeology, P.O. Box 2087, Santa Fe, NM  87504, United States; Cox, J.R., Center for New Mexico Archaeology, P.O. Box 2087, Santa Fe, NM  87504, United States; Mackenzie, M., Conservation Unit, Museum of New Mexico, P.O. Box 2087, Santa Fe, NM  87504, United States; Wacker, L., Laboratory of Ion Beam Physics, ETH Zűürich, HPK, H29, Otto-Stern-Weg 5, Züűrich, CH-8093, Switzerland
Abstract: A new low energy plasma system laboratory at the Center for New Mexico Archaeology (Santa Fe, New Mexico) for radiocarbon sampling has recently been established. Significant improvements to previous systems have been instituted, not only in the system itself, but also in experimental procedures. Multiple chambers for sampling have been added to increase efficiency. Dual internal secondary argon and oxygen storage chambers are added for quick refilling purposes. Masking procedures are also being tested to isolate specific carbon-bearing material from the rest of sample in the form of aluminium foil or alumina (aluminium oxide powder). © Archaeopress and the authors 2016.

Authors: Nizam N.M., Zulkhfl M.H., Khor A.C., Mohamed M.R., Sulaiman M.H.
Title: Design and development of vanadium redox flow battery (V-RFB) cell stack
Affiliations: Sustainable Energy and Power Electronics Research Cluster (SuPER), Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Universiti Malaysia Pahang, Pekan, Pahang, 26600, Malaysia

Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to demonstrate the summarization of work on experimental characterisation of vanadium redox flow battery (V-RFB). The aim of the study is to design a functional prototype of V-RFB and investigate the performance of characterisation of V-RFB at specific current density. Experiment was carried on 110.25cm2 prototype of unit cell. The results from the performance test of the developed V-RFB including fe obstacles faced have been presented and analysed. Further works is discussed. © 2016 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sujali S., Mohamed M.R., Mad Don S.A., Yusoff N.
Title: Method approaches to prevent leakage cell stack of vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB)
Affiliations: Sustainable Energy and Power Electronics Research Group, Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering Universiti, Pahang Pekan Pahang, 26600, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Sujali, S., Sustainable Energy and Power Electronics Research Group, Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering Universiti, Pahang Pekan Pahang, 26600, Malaysia; Mohamed, M.R., Sustainable Energy and Power Electronics Research Group, Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering Universiti, Pahang Pekan Pahang, 26600, Malaysia; Mad Don, S.A., Sustainable Energy and Power Electronics Research Group, Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering Universiti, Pahang Pekan Pahang, 26600, Malaysia; Yusoff, N., Sustainable Energy and Power Electronics Research Group, Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering Universiti, Pahang Pekan Pahang, 26600, Malaysia
Abstract: This paper present the method to solve the leakage problem for a unit cell Vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB) in detecting the several main component involved and depict the weakness matter that causes leakage in order to improve the cell performance of VRFB. The 110.25cm2 unit cell stack of VRFB is carried out and setup with different size of rubber seal, membrane, type of fitting and layer of carbon felt use to elucidate the leakage problem. Result demonstrated that the usage of 3.0mm rubber seal, 12cm x 12cm Nafion 117 membrane, polypropylene type fitting and double layer of carbon felt showed positive feedback on solving the vanadium leakage. Suggestion for development and material improvements is highlighted. © 2016 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Eu-Tjin C., Huat C.K., Seng L.Y.
Title: Control strategies in energy storage system for standalone power systems
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering and Science, Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Eu-Tjin, C., Faculty of Engineering and Science, Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman, Malaysia; Huat, C.K., Faculty of Engineering and Science, Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman, Malaysia; Seng, L.Y., Faculty of Engineering and Science, Universiti Tunku Abdul Rahman, Malaysia
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems can be one of the possible energy sources to complement the diesel generators in the remote areas, to reduce the reliance on diesel generators. This translates into the reduced fossil fuel consumption, hence bringing an economic benefit to residents in the remote areas. Energy storage system offers a solution which can be used in conjunction with the PV-diesel generator system. The energy storage system (ESS) ensures energy supply security and reliability by storing up excess solar energy for later use in the energy deficit situation. In this study, a PV-Battery-Diesel Generator system is modelled in Matlab Simulink. The main purpose of the study is to obtain the optimal system size and control strategy which yields the minimum cost of energy. Load following (LF) and cycle charging (CC) control strategies are devised for the model developed. Various component sizes for PV and battery are simulated using the LF and CC control strategy. The simulation results show that the Cost of Electricity (COE) reduction using the PV-battery-diesel generator is as high as 10.6%. © 2016 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Battery; Diesel generator; Energy management; Energy Storage System; Off-grid

Authors: Koohi-Kamali S., Rahim N.A., Mokhlis H.
Title: Coordinated control of smart microgrid considering variability in load demand and generation
Affiliations: UM Power Energy Dedicated Advanced Centre (UMPEDAC), Wisma RandD UM, Level 4, Jalan Pantai Baharu Kuala Lumpur, 59990, Malaysia; Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, 50603, Malaysia; Renewable Energy Research Group, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, 21589, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Koohi-Kamali, S., UM Power Energy Dedicated Advanced Centre (UMPEDAC), Wisma RandD UM, Level 4, Jalan Pantai Baharu Kuala Lumpur, 59990, Malaysia; Rahim, N.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, 50603, Malaysia; Mokhlis, H., Renewable Energy Research Group, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, 21589, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Photovoltaic distributed generation (PVDG) can negatively influence the operation of power grid which is connected to. This happens because of the intermittent nature of sunlight. Battery storage system can be a proper solution to resolve this problem if it is exploited by a reliable power management system (PMS). This work proposes a PMS which controls a microgrid (MG) including both rotary and electronically interfaced (EI) units. MG is subject to supply local load in a centralized fashion and hence to limit power oscillations caused by the load and generation. To assess the operational effectiveness of MG and PMS, PSCAD is chosen as the simulating platform. Different test cases are arranged reflecting realistic data in Peninsular Malaysia. All the results confirm the successful operation of MG and its PMS in satisfying the load demand and generation. © 2016 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electrical energy storage; Power management system; Power smoothing index; Smart grid; Solar photovoltaic
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Electric power transmission networks; Power management; Solar power generation; Storage management; Electrical energy storages; Power management systems; Power smoothing; Smart grid; Solar photovoltaics; Smart power grids

Authors: Uddin M., Romlie M.F., Abdullah M.F.
Title: Feasibility study of grid connected solar home system: The perspective of Malaysia
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Tronoh, Perak, 32610, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Uddin, M., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Tronoh, Perak, 32610, Malaysia; Romlie, M.F., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Tronoh, Perak, 32610, Malaysia; Abdullah, M.F., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Tronoh, Perak, 32610, Malaysia
Abstract: The main objective of this study is to explore opportunities to move forward to environment-friendly energy production in Malaysia. The environmental effects of fossil fuel usage and increasing electricity demand are the main factor driving towards renewable technology. To achieve the goal, this paper proposes a Grid Connected Solar Home System (GCSHS). The proposed GCSHS consists of solar and battery energy storage system, connected to the grid. Using HOMER software a simulation is carried out to examine the feasibility of GCSHS. From simulation result it is seen, per kWh energy of the proposed system is varied from USD 0.054 to 0.088. Considering the carbon tax, clean development mechanisms and oil price increase, this cost will be reduced. Using of GCSHS has both economic and environmental benefits. Cost benefit, environmental benefit, system description, and detail analysis are presented in this study. © 2016 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Nasif M.S., Kumar G.A., Roslan R.
Title: An effective optimization of rainwater harvesting system in hotel and hospital buildings
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Seri Iskandar, Perak, 32610, Malaysia; Reliability and Maintenance Department, PETRONAS Carigali SDN. Bhd, Kompleks Operasi PETRONAS, Kerteh, Terengganu, 24300, Malaysia
